turns.content: I woke up this morning feeling the whole room is spinning when i was sitting down. I went to the bathroom walking unsteadily, as i tried to focus i feel nauseous. I try to vomit but it wont come out.. After taking panadol and sleep for few hours, i still feel the same.. By the way, if i lay down or sit down, my head do not spin, only when i want to move around then i feel the whole world is spinning.. And it is normal stomach discomfort at the same time? Earlier after i relieved myself, the spinning lessen so i am not sure whether its connected or coincidences.. Thank you doc!

Apologies for your discomfort. To better comprehend your symptoms, kindly respond to these queries:
1. Have you noticed any loss of hearing or ear ringing?
2. Have you suffered any head injuries or infections recently?
3. Does any particular position intensify or alleviate the spinning sensation?

Hi Doc, I haven't noticed any loss of hearing or ear ringing. No recent head injuries or infections either. As for the spinning sensation, it gets worse when I stand up or try to walk around. It's a little better when I sit or lie down.

Thank you for the information. It's helpful to know that your symptoms are positional. A few more questions:
1. Have you had any recent changes in your medications?
2. Do you have any other symptoms such as a fever, headache, or neck stiffness?
3. Have you experienced similar episodes in the past?

Actually, I don't take any regular medications, so no changes there. I don't have a fever or neck stiffness, but I do have a slight headache. The headache is not too bad, just a dull ache. As for similar episodes, I can't recall experiencing anything exactly like this before. It's really quite unsettling.

I understand how unsettling this must be for you. Your symptoms suggest a condition called benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV), which occurs when tiny calcium particles clump up in the inner ear. This can cause brief episodes of mild to intense dizziness, often triggered by specific changes in the position of your head.

Here's our plan:
1. Rest and avoid sudden head movements.
2. Stay hydrated and eat light meals to help with the nausea.
3. Over-the-counter medications like meclizine or dimenhydrinate can help with the dizziness and nausea.

Please seek immediate medical attention if the dizziness persists for more than a few days, you have a high fever, severe headache, chest pain, difficulty speaking, or if you faint.

Wow, I didn't realize it could be something related to my ear! Thanks for the advice, I'll try to rest and avoid sudden movements. I do have a question, though. Can this just happen out of nowhere like it did? I mean, I didn't hit my head or anything. And what about the stomach discomfort? Does that have something to do with this condition as well?

Yes, BPPV can indeed occur spontaneously, often due to age-related changes, though the exact cause is often unknown. As for your stomach discomfort, it could be related to the vertigo as some people experience nausea or even vomiting due to the dizziness.

1. Could you describe the stomach discomfort in more detail?
2. Is it related to eating or does it occur at any time?
3. Have you noticed any changes in your bowel movements?

My baby has been pooing 5-6 times a day for a week. In the last few days it has increased to 7 and they are very watery with green stringy bits in them. He does not seem unwell i.e no temperature and still eating. He now has a very bad nappy rash from the pooing ...help!

I'm sorry to hear your baby is having these issues. To help me understand better, could you please tell me the baby's age? Also, has there been any recent changes in his diet or introduction of new foods? Lastly, has there been any blood or mucus in the stools?

He's just turned 6 months old. We haven't started him on solids yet, so no changes in diet. I didn't notice any blood, but what does mucus look like in a baby's stool? I'm not sure if what I thought was stringy bits could be mucus.

Mucus in a baby's stool can look like clear or white slimy streaks. It can sometimes be mistaken for undigested food. Given your baby's age and symptoms, this could be a viral gastroenteritis, which is common and usually resolves on its own. However, it could also be a sign of a food intolerance or infection. Has your baby been exposed to anyone sick recently? Are there any signs of dehydration, like fewer wet diapers, dry mouth, or sunken eyes? And how is the baby's weight gain?

No one in our house has been sick, so I don't think he's been exposed to any illness. As for signs of dehydration, I haven't noticed a decrease in wet nappies. His mouth doesn't seem dry, but his eyes... I'm not sure. I never really thought to look for that, to be honest. His weight gain had been good at his last checkup, but that was a little over a month ago. The rash is really worrying me too, it seems quite sore.

I understand your concern. For the diaper rash, you can try frequent diaper changes, use of a barrier cream, and allowing some diaper-free time to let the skin air out. Regarding the diarrhea, it's reassuring that he's not showing signs of dehydration and his weight gain has been good. However, it's important to monitor his condition closely. Is he showing any signs of discomfort or fussiness? Has the frequency of his bowel movements continued to increase? And have you noticed any changes in his feeding habits?

Yes, he does seem a bit fussier than usual, especially during diaper changes. His bowel movements are still around 7 times a day and they're still very watery. He's been feeding as normal, though. Doesn't seem to have lost his appetite at all. Maybe I should start keeping a closer eye on his eyes and mouth for signs of dehydration?

Yes, it would be beneficial to keep an eye out for signs of dehydration. It's good that he's still feeding well and not showing severe signs of illness. Given the ongoing diarrhea, it's possible he has a viral infection like rotavirus, which is common in infants and can cause increased fussiness and diaper rash. Alternatively, this could be a sign of a developing food intolerance.

Here's a plan:
1. Continue to monitor for signs of dehydration.
2. Try to soothe the diaper rash as previously discussed.
3. If the diarrhea persists for more than a week or if he develops a fever, vomiting, or signs of dehydration, seek immediate medical attention.

Please remember, if his condition worsens or if you're ever in doubt, don't hesitate to seek urgent medical care.

Hello, My husband is taking Oxycodone due to a broken leg/surgery. He has been taking this pain medication for one month. We are trying to conceive our second baby. Will this medication afect the fetus? Or the health of the baby? Or can it bring birth defects? Thank you.

Oxycodone is a strong opioid medication used for pain control. While it's not typically associated with birth defects, it can potentially cause problems if a baby is exposed to it regularly in the womb, such as neonatal opioid withdrawal syndrome. However, it's important to clarify a few things:
1. Is your husband currently trying to reduce his use of Oxycodone under medical supervision?
2. Are there any other medications he is currently taking?
3. Does he have any other health conditions?

Yes, my husband is under the supervision of his doctor to gradually reduce the Oxycodone. He's not taking any other medications right now, and he doesn't have any other health conditions. We are just worried if his Oxycodone use could harm the baby we are trying to conceive.

Thank you for providing that information. It's important to note that the father's use of oxycodone doesn't directly affect the fetus. The main concern would be if the mother was taking the medication during pregnancy. However, it's always a good idea to discuss any medication use with your healthcare provider when planning to conceive.

Here's a plan:
1. Continue to follow the doctor's guidance on tapering off the Oxycodone.
2. Maintain a healthy lifestyle, including regular exercise and a balanced diet.
3. Schedule a preconception check-up for both of you to discuss any potential health concerns.

Please seek immediate medical attention if your husband experiences severe withdrawal symptoms such as agitation, fever, rapid heartbeat, or hallucinations while tapering off the medication.

Oh, that's a relief to hear. We were so worried about the baby's health. We'll continue following the doctor's advice on reducing the Oxycodone. And we'll definitely schedule a preconception check-up soon. Thanks for your advice. We appreciate it.

You're welcome! I'm glad I could help alleviate your concerns. It's great to hear that you're planning a preconception check-up. Remember, it's important to share all your health concerns and lifestyle habits with your healthcare provider during this visit. If you or your husband have any new or worsening symptoms, don't hesitate to reach out to your healthcare provider. Best of luck on your journey to expanding your family!

Thank you again for all of your advice. We are really trying to be proactive and make sure we're doing everything right for our future baby. We'll definitely be open and share all the details with our healthcare provider during the preconception check-up.

That's a great approach! Being proactive and open with your healthcare provider will help ensure the best possible health for both you and your future baby. Remember, it's also important to maintain a healthy lifestyle, including regular exercise, a balanced diet, and avoiding alcohol and tobacco. If you have any further questions or concerns in the future, don't hesitate to reach out. Best wishes on your journey to parenthood.

lump under left nipple and stomach pain (male) Hi,I have recently noticed a few weeks ago a lump under my nipple, it hurts to touch and is about the size of a quarter. Also I have bern experiencing stomach pains that prevent me from eating. I immediatly feel full and have extreme pain. Please help

I'm sorry to hear you're feeling this way. To better understand your symptoms, could you please tell me more about the stomach pain - where exactly is it located and does it radiate anywhere? Also, have you noticed any changes in your bowel movements or weight recently? Lastly, have you had any fever, night sweats, or other systemic symptoms?

The stomach pain feels like it's right in the middle of my abdomen, kind of like a gnawing feeling. It doesn't really radiate anywhere, just stays in that spot. I can't say I've noticed any changes in my bowel movements or weight. I've not had a fever or night sweats either. It's just the pain and feeling full really quickly when I try to eat something.

Thank you for the additional information. To help narrow down the cause of your symptoms, could you please tell me if you've noticed any changes in the color of your skin or eyes, such as yellowing? Do you have any history of gastrointestinal issues, like ulcers or gastritis? Lastly, is the lump under your nipple red, warm, or showing any changes in size or shape?

No, I haven't noticed any yellowing in my skin or eyes. And I've never had any issues with my stomach before, so this is all new to me. As for the lump, I don't think it's gotten any bigger since I first noticed it, but it is a bit red and it feels warm and tender when I touch it. This is all just so worrying.

I understand your concern. Based on your symptoms, two conditions come to mind: gastritis or peptic ulcer disease could explain your stomach pain and early satiety, while the lump under your nipple could be gynecomastia or an infection.

Here's our plan:
1. For your stomach pain, try over-the-counter antacids and avoid spicy, fatty, or caffeinated foods.
2. For the lump, apply a warm compress and monitor for changes.
3. Schedule an appointment with your primary care doctor for further evaluation.

Please seek immediate medical attention if you experience severe abdominal pain, vomiting blood, black stools, or if the lump becomes significantly larger, more painful, or starts to drain.

Okay, thank you for the advice. I'll get started on the antacids, watch my diet, and try the warm compress for the lump. I'm going to try and set up an appointment with my doctor as soon as I can. I'm just really anxious about all of this, so I appreciate your help. I'll be sure to look out for any of the symptoms you mentioned.

I understand your anxiety, and it's good to hear you're taking steps to manage your symptoms and arrange a doctor's visit. Remember, it's important to discuss both your abdominal pain and the lump under your nipple with your doctor. In the meantime, try to stay hydrated and maintain a balanced diet as much as your symptoms allow. If your symptoms worsen or you become more concerned, don't hesitate to seek immediate medical attention.

I have a 5 month old baby who is very congested with a terrible cough. Its rattly/raspy and croupy sounding cough. She started choking on her coughs and the mucous that has come up. She also has a fever and runny nose. Should i take her to urgent care?

I'm sorry to hear that your baby is unwell. It's important to clarify a few things:
1. How high is her fever?
2. Has she been eating and drinking normally?
3. Has there been any change in her activity level or alertness?
If her fever is very high, she's not eating or drinking, or she seems less alert than usual, it would be best to take her to urgent care immediately.

Her fever is around 101. She's been eating a little less than usual, but still drinking her milk. She's a bit more fussy and less active than usual. I'm really worried about her cough and the choking, it's really scary to see.

I understand your concern, it's distressing to see your baby unwell. To help me understand better:
1. How many times has she choked on her cough or mucus?
2. Is she having any difficulty breathing or bluish color around her lips or face?
3. Is the cough worsening, improving, or staying the same?
If she's choking frequently, having difficulty breathing, or showing any bluish color, these are signs of a potential emergency and she should be taken to urgent care immediately.

She's choked a few times now, mainly after a bout of coughing. I haven't noticed any bluish color but it's so hard to tell with all the crying and coughing. Her cough seems to be the same, if not a bit worse since this morning. I'm just not sure what to do to help her.

I understand your worry. Given your baby's symptoms, it's best to take her to urgent care immediately. The choking, worsening cough, and decreased activity level are concerning. At urgent care, they can assess her breathing, hydration status, and overall condition more thoroughly. If her condition worsens on the way, such as increased difficulty breathing or becoming less responsive, please call an ambulance.
Okay, I'll take her to urgent care right away. I just hope they can make her feel better soon. It's so hard seeing her like this. Thank you for your help.

You're doing the right thing by taking her to urgent care. They are equipped to help her. Remember, if she seems to worsen at any point, don't hesitate to call an ambulance. Please update me on her condition when you can. I hope your baby feels better soon.

I am F 38 in good shape work out (do triathlons) regular but have had back pain from different reasons throughout my life now I every so often wake up with severe lower back, hip pain for no reason. today the pain is almost taking my breathe away when i move. It is a dull pain when i am just lying down but the moment I make any sort of movement I have sharp and sometimes shooting pain down my legs.

I'm sorry to hear about your pain. To better understand your condition, could you please tell me when this pain started, if there's anything that makes it better or worse, and if you've noticed any numbness, tingling, or weakness in your legs?

The pain started a couple of years ago, but it's been on and off. Lately though, it's been a lot more frequent. Heat packs seem to offer some relief, but the moment I move, the sharp pain returns. As for numbness or tingling, I can't say I've noticed anything like that, but my legs do feel a bit weak when the pain is at its worst.

Thank you for sharing those details. It's important to understand if there's a pattern to your pain. Does it worsen with certain activities or movements, such as bending or lifting? Have you had any recent injuries or falls? Lastly, have you noticed any changes in bowel or bladder control since the onset of this pain?

I haven't had any recent injuries or falls that I can think of. For movements, it's weird because things like bending or lifting don't always make it worse. Sometimes, just getting out of bed can trigger the pain. And no, I haven't noticed any changes in my bowel or bladder control. Just this disturbing back and hip pain.

Your symptoms suggest a few possible causes, such as sciatica or a lumbar disc herniation. Sciatica can cause sharp, shooting pain down the legs, often worsened by movement. A herniated disc could cause similar symptoms, and your history of back pain could make you more susceptible.

Plan:
1. Try over-the-counter pain relievers like ibuprofen, if you're not allergic, to manage your pain.
2. Continue using heat packs as they seem to provide some relief.
3. Consider physical therapy exercises for lower back pain.
4. If the pain persists or worsens, please seek medical attention.

Please seek immediate medical attention if you experience loss of bowel or bladder control, severe weakness in your legs, or if the pain becomes unbearable.

Oh, a herniated disc or sciatica sounds really serious. I've been trying to manage with over-the-counter pain relief, but it's still pretty painful. As for the physical therapy exercises, I'm a little worried about making the pain worse. And well, what if the pain doesn't go away? I can't even imagine living like this for the rest of my life.

I understand your concerns. It's important to remember that both sciatica and herniated discs are treatable conditions. If over-the-counter medications aren't providing enough relief, it may be time to seek medical attention. A healthcare provider can provide a more accurate diagnosis and treatment plan. As for physical therapy, a trained therapist can guide you through safe exercises that can help alleviate your pain. Have you considered scheduling an appointment with a healthcare provider or a physical therapist? If the pain doesn't improve, would you be open to exploring other treatment options such as prescription medications or, in severe cases, surgery?

sir, MY uncle has ILD-Interstitial Lung disease.from my research over google i found that the cause is important to be known. the cause wat i feel is due to breakage of acid bottle in bathroom which caused lot of smoke and that time he wasnot able to be normal for 15-20 minutes. then he was normal .may be that would have been the reason for this ILD. Please suggest wat we should do

I understand your concerns about your uncle's Interstitial Lung Disease (ILD). To help clarify, can you tell me when the incident with the acid bottle occurred and when your uncle was diagnosed with ILD? Also, has he had any other exposure to harmful substances or does he have any other medical conditions?

The acid bottle incident happened around 6 months ago. My uncle was diagnosed with ILD just a month back. I don't know of any other harmful exposure, he's always been careful. He has diabetes, if that's of any relevance. I'm just so worried for him.

I understand your concern. The timing of the acid incident and the diagnosis of ILD could be related, but it's also important to consider other factors. ILD can be caused by many things, including certain medications, environmental factors, and other medical conditions. Diabetes itself doesn't typically cause ILD, but it's important to manage it well. Has your uncle seen a pulmonologist (lung specialist)? Has he had any imaging tests like a CT scan of his chest? What medications is he currently taking for his diabetes and ILD?

Yes, he has seen a pulmonologist and undergone a CT scan as well. He's been taking Metformin for his diabetes. As for the ILD, he was prescribed some medication, but I can't recall the name right now. I'll look it up and let you know. Could you please tell me more about these environmental factors? We live in a busy city with a lot of pollution, could that be a cause?

Environmental factors can indeed contribute to ILD. Long-term exposure to air pollutants, certain dusts (like asbestos or silica), and some molds can increase the risk. Living in a city with high pollution could potentially contribute, but it's usually prolonged, significant exposure that leads to ILD.

Regarding your uncle's medication, it would be helpful to know the specific drug for his ILD as different medications can have different effects and side effects.

Lastly, has your uncle experienced any changes in his symptoms recently? Any worsening of breathlessness, cough, or fatigue?

I see, I never thought the city's pollution could also be a factor. As for symptoms, he does complain about feeling breathless more often and he seems to tire easily these days. I'll get back to you with the name of the ILD medication as soon as I can. It's just been a lot to take in, you know?

I understand this is a challenging time for you and your family. Breathlessness and fatigue can be symptoms of ILD progression, but they can also be due to other factors like poor diabetes control or anemia. Once you have the name of the ILD medication, we can discuss it further. In the meantime, it would be beneficial for your uncle to continue monitoring his symptoms and report any significant changes to his pulmonologist. If he experiences severe breathlessness or chest pain, he should seek immediate medical attention.

my husband was working on a project in the house and all of a sudden a bump about the size of a half dollar appeard on his left leg inside below the knee. He is 69 years old and had triple by pass surgery 7 years ago. It stung when it first happened. Doesn t hurt now. He is seated with his leg ellevated. Is this an emergency?

I'm here to help. Can you tell me if the bump is red, warm, or swollen? Did your husband injure his leg or was there any trauma? Is he experiencing any other symptoms like shortness of breath or chest pain?

Well, the bump is a little red and warm but I wouldn't say it's swollen. He was just doing some odd jobs around the house, nothing that should have caused an injury as such. As for other symptoms, he says he feels fine, no chest pain or shortness of breath. I was just worried because of his heart history, you know.

I understand your concern given his heart history. To further assess, could you please tell me if the skin over the bump is intact or if there's any bleeding? Also, is there any change in the color of his leg or foot? Lastly, does he have any history of blood clotting disorders or is he currently on blood thinners?

The skin over the bump seems unbroken and there's no bleeding. His leg and foot look normal to me, no changes in color. He's never had any blood clotting disorders as far as I know. He's on aspirin, but that's about it. I'm just worried because it came out of nowhere.

Thank you for the additional information. Based on what you've described, it's possible that your husband has developed a local reaction to something, perhaps an insect bite or contact with an irritant. However, given his age and heart history, we should be cautious. Here's what I recommend:

1. Apply a cold compress to the area to reduce any inflammation.
2. Monitor for any changes, such as increased redness, warmth, swelling, or pain.
3. If any new symptoms develop, like fever, chest pain, or shortness of breath, seek immediate medical attention.

This is not an emergency at this moment, but if the bump grows rapidly, becomes painful, or if he develops systemic symptoms, please take him to the emergency department.

Alright, a cold compress. I can do that. I'll definitely keep an eye on it and watch out for any changes. It's a bit of a relief to know it's not an emergency right now. I'm still concerned, but I feel a bit better knowing what to watch for. Thanks for your help.

You're welcome. It's important to stay vigilant in situations like these. If the bump doesn't improve or worsens over the next 48 hours, I recommend seeking medical attention. Also, if he develops any new symptoms, don't hesitate to seek immediate care. Is there anything else you're concerned about at this moment?

hi my nine year old son had a cough and flu symptons three months ago and the chesty sounding cough and green phlegm still remains. it did seem to get better but never totally went and has now picked up again...he has only ever had antibiotics once in his live which suggests he his generally fitand well and active...never short of breath or weezy...so why would this be....

I'm sorry to hear your son is experiencing this. To help me understand better, could you please answer the following questions:
1. Has your son been exposed to anyone with a similar prolonged cough or any known respiratory infections recently?
2. Has he had any fever, weight loss, or night sweats in the past three months?
3. Does his cough worsen with physical activity or at certain times of the day?

Hi, thanks for getting back to me. No, he hasn't been around anyone with a long-term cough or any respiratory infections that we're aware of. He's been pretty stable in terms of weight and hasn't complained about night sweats. As for his cough, it doesn't really get worse with physical activity, but it does seem to be a bit more noticeable in the mornings, maybe?

Thank you for the information. It's helpful to know that his symptoms are more pronounced in the morning. A few more questions to help narrow down the possibilities:
1. Has your son been exposed to any potential irritants, such as secondhand smoke, dust, or pets?
2. Has he experienced any other symptoms such as sore throat, ear pain, or sinus congestion?
3. Does he have any history of allergies or asthma?

No, we don't have any smokers in the house nor does he get exposed to secondhand smoke. We do have a dog, but he's been around him since he was a puppy and never had any issues. As for other symptoms, he did have a bit of a sore throat and a stuffy nose when the cough first started, but that's pretty much cleared up now. He hasn't mentioned any ear pain. He doesn't have any known allergies or asthma either. It's just this lingering cough that we can't seem to shake off.

Thank you for the additional information. Based on what you've shared, your son's lingering cough could be due to a few possibilities: post-viral cough, which can persist for weeks after a respiratory infection; or chronic bronchitis, which is less common in children but can occur.

Here's our plan:
1. Continue monitoring his symptoms at home.
2. Try using a humidifier in his room at night, as dry air can irritate the throat and prolong coughing.
3. Encourage him to drink plenty of fluids to help thin out the mucus.

If his cough doesn't improve in the next 2 weeks, or if he develops new symptoms like fever, difficulty breathing, or chest pain, please seek medical attention immediately.

Okay, that's reassuring. We'll monitor his symptoms and try out the humidifier and fluids like you suggested. It's just so hard seeing him with this persistent cough. I'll definitely get him to a doctor if it doesn't improve or if he shows any of those serious symptoms you mentioned. Thanks for the advice!

You're welcome. I understand your concern; it's tough when our children aren't feeling well. Remember, the goal is to see some improvement over the next two weeks with these measures. If his cough remains the same or worsens, please don't hesitate to seek medical attention. In the meantime, is he up-to-date with his vaccinations, including the flu shot? And has he been washing his hands regularly, especially at school?

gyno problemsfor the past few months, I have been having issues with my vagina. there always seems to be something wrong with me. its either an infection or a yeast infection from the medication used to treat the previous infection or a herpes outbreak as a result of a yeast infection. most recently, I had a uti. I was treated for that and everything seemed fine, until after I finished the medication. it still hurt when I had sex and still is uncomfortable to pee. I dont know whats going on and this has been going on for months.

I'm sorry to hear you're experiencing these issues. To help me understand better, could you please tell me:
1. How long after finishing the UTI medication did the discomfort during sex and urination start?
2. Are there any other symptoms like fever, lower abdominal pain, or unusual vaginal discharge?
3. Have you had any recent changes in your sexual partners or contraceptive methods?

I finished the UTI medication about 2 weeks ago and the discomfort during sex and urination started a few days after that. I mean, I do have some lower abdominal pain, but I thought it was just from my period. As for the discharge, it's been a bit different lately, kind of thicker than normal. And no, I've been with the same partner for a few years now and I've been on the pill for just as long.

Thank you for providing those details. It's possible that your symptoms could be due to a persistent or recurrent urinary tract infection, a different type of infection, or a side effect from your medication.
1. Did you have a urine culture done when you were diagnosed with the UTI?
2. Have you noticed any blood in your urine or changes in its color or smell?
3. Have you experienced any itching or burning sensation in the vaginal area?

No, I didn't have a urine culture done. They just told me it was a UTI and gave me the medication. As for the urine, it's been a bit darker than usual, but I haven't noticed any blood. And yeah, there is some itching and a bit of a burning feeling down there. It's just so frustrating not knowing what's wrong.

I understand your frustration. Based on your symptoms, we should consider recurrent UTI, a possible vaginal infection (like bacterial vaginosis or yeast), or an adverse effect of your medication. Here's our plan:

1. Get a urine culture to confirm if the UTI has cleared or recurred.
2. Consider a vaginal swab to identify any possible infection.
3. Review your medications for potential side effects.

Please seek immediate care if you develop high fever, severe abdominal pain, or if your symptoms significantly worsen.
Okay, that sounds like a good plan. At least now I feel like I'm getting somewhere. I'll get the tests done and hopefully, we can figure out what's going on. Thanks for your help.

You're welcome. After you've completed the tests, please share the results so we can decide on the next steps. In the meantime, try to stay hydrated and avoid any activities, like sexual intercourse, that may exacerbate the discomfort. If you have any questions or concerns, don't hesitate to reach out.

I have found that I have an allergy to leotensin. They have taken me off of everything....I found in the information that one side effect if the red skin lensions with a purple center. I was looking to see if there was anything I could do to help the spots go away. I am a dental hygienist and I will be working the next two days. Is there anything that would cover them, so the patients would not be aware???

I'm sorry to hear about your skin lesions. To better understand your situation, could you please tell me:
1. How long ago did these lesions appear?
2. Are they painful or itchy?
3. Have you noticed any other symptoms like fever, joint pain, or swelling?
The spots showed up about a week ago. They aren't really painful, just a bit itchy sometimes. And no, I haven't noticed any other symptoms like fever or joint pain. Just these weird spots.

Thank you for the additional information. Given your recent history of leotensin use and the description of your skin lesions, this could be a drug reaction. However, other possibilities include a viral rash or a skin condition like vasculitis.

Here's what I suggest:
1. Apply over-the-counter hydrocortisone cream to the itchy spots, unless they're open or infected.
2. Avoid scratching to prevent infection.
3. Cover the spots with a bandage or clothing if you're concerned about them being visible at work.
4. Schedule an appointment with a dermatologist for a definitive diagnosis.

Please seek immediate medical attention if you develop symptoms like difficulty breathing, swelling of the face or mouth, or worsening skin lesions.

Okay, thanks for the advice. I'll try the hydrocortisone cream and make sure to cover them up. As for seeing a dermatologist, can this wait a couple of days till my work schedule clears up? I don't want to leave my patients hanging. And, of course, I'll keep an eye out for any worsening symptoms.

Yes, you can wait a couple of days to see a dermatologist, especially since your symptoms are not severe and you're not experiencing any other concerning symptoms. However, if your skin lesions start to spread rapidly, become painful, or if you develop any new symptoms, please seek immediate medical attention. In the meantime, continue with the hydrocortisone cream and covering the spots.

Alright, I'll keep that in mind. I just hope these spots don't get worse. It's a bit embarrassing, you know? Especially since people might think it's contagious or something while I'm at work. I'll try to cover them up as much as I can. Thanks for your help.

I understand your concerns about the appearance of the spots. Rest assured, if this is a drug reaction, it's not contagious. Continue covering them up at work for your comfort. Remember to monitor for any changes and seek immediate care if needed. Let's touch base again in a few days to see how you're doing, or sooner if your symptoms worsen.

Hi my name is Wendy I ve been having an issue for the last couple of months or so I been having severe pain in my lower back around the front into the groin area and its radiating down my thigh and so on I am currently a cancer patient nobody seems to be able to tell me what it could be the pain is so bad that it brings tears to my eyes would you possibly know what it could be or might be

I'm sorry to hear you're in such discomfort, Wendy. To better understand your situation, could you please tell me:
1. What type of cancer are you currently being treated for?
2. Have you had any imaging studies (like CT, MRI) for this pain?
3. Are there any specific movements or activities that make the pain worse or better?

I'm being treated for breast cancer. I haven't had any imaging done specifically for the pain, but I've had some scans for my cancer treatment. 2. Avoid eating 2-3 hours before bedtime and elevate the head of your bed to prevent acid reflux during sleep.
3. Limit or avoid foods that trigger your symptoms, like spicy foods and coffee.
